column1: Will the city council building in Kherson, Ukraine, be under Ukrainian control on 25 November 2022, according to the Institute for the Study of War?
column6: ['Society', 'Security and Conflict']
Update
control means every position filled
Very likely yes.
It is as good as taken already

Supply lines Russian are shortening on human and other consumables.
Given recent developments in Ukraine - this seems far more probable than not.

Updating in light of recent events with Ukraine retaking the city. It is possible that Russia will launch a counter offensive, but that is less probable as the closing date of the questions gets closer (currently only 3 days away).
Russia announced its retreat, and its troops are receding. Also, Ukrainian troops have moved in and completely occupied the city, making it a fortress against Russia's diminishing forces.
Modified forecast based on news that Russians are leaving Kherson.

Its happening. There is no way Russia is taking back Kherson. The Ukrainians have it, it seems like the Russian retreat was legitimate, an idea backed up by how Putin distanced himself from it. Also, winter is coming. Also, this question ends in 5 days.
https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/nov/20/the-russians-have-gone-now-kherson-faces-a-relentless-new-enemy-winter
The Russians may raze Kherson, but they will never step foot there again.
Think they are already
This Q may be resolved based on what shows up on the ISW map rather than what everybody in the world knows. Seems odd.
Chances of Russia launching a counter offensive to claim the building back is very less. Russia seems to be focusing on expanding the conflict through sporadic attacks in other parts.

It seems Ukrainian forces are in control on that side of the river and a major bridge was blown up. In war, lots of things can happen though, I'll reserve 2% for a change in direction. I'd guess the most likely is a shelling or air bombing that put it back in Russian control. I actually think there is a chance it is in a neutral category of no-ones-land at some point, which would fail the question as written (asks about Ukrainian control, not Russian) but it seems the ISW doesn't have a category for that on their map, so I guess that isn't in this case.
Updating to reflect recent events.
Updating my forecast to reflect recent events.
Recent developments with Russia retreating from Kherson and creating a barrier by blowing up a bridge.
they are there already
Ukraine is now officially in control of Kherson after having moved into the city when Russia withdrew from it.
I'll have taken a hit on my initial predictions. I'll blame fog of war but really I was trying to be too clever by ignoring the 35% crowd avg.
Yesssss! Free Kherson! https://www.cnn.com/2022/11/12/europe/kherson-city-ukraine-russia-intl/index.html

I waited a few days to update my forecast. The decider reference, https://storymaps.arcgis.com/stories/36a7f6a6f5a9448496de641cf64bd375 shows that Kherson's circle symbol is within the claimed Ukrainian counter-offensive (blue) so updating to crowd forecast.
“the owls are not what they seem”
Kherson under Ukrainian control

As @SE-Meyer has pointed out to me, this question asks ". . . under Ukrainian control on 25 November. . . " If there's a successful RU counter-attack in the next 2 weeks this question would flip.

Some updates due to historic news! (1) https://www.nytimes.com/live/2022/11/11/world/ukraine-war-news-russia-updates; and (2) https://www.nytimes.com/2022/11/11/world/europe/kherson-ukraine-russia.html.
Yesterday, troops swooped into Kherson and took control of the central square as Russian troops retreated. Article here cnn.com/2022/11/11/europe/russian-troops-leave-kherson-region-intl/index.html
Congratulations to The People of Ukraine Slava Ukrainiya.
The ISW map has changed!
What if the local dam bursts? There's reported damage to it. I don't think it'll affect the city council building (very naive assumption) but who knows?
news update
The media is reporting that Kherson is back under Ukrainian control.
Control is now transferred. Unlikely to fall to Russians by end of forecasting period as the Russians are regrouping/on the back foot.
#BravoZulu
I’ll take a bad score on this one, was totally wrong on how long a withdrawal would take. I think control is not yet established, but this tweet suggests it’s not far away

Russia has now retreated from the city

No trap
Appear to be in city already, seems like probability of Russia retaking it in the short time window here is very low
Moving a bit faster than I imagined. Now, does it all go smoothly and do they keep it?
Definition of "control":

Russian authorities confirm that the Russian military has moved to the eastern bank of the Dnipro River and blown the bridge to prohibit a Ukrainian advance across it. These combined factors lead me to increase my forecast. The Ukrainian military will likely advance cautiously into the city which impacts the timing of when they'll reassert control. I think it's safe to say that Russia is seeking to cede Kherson back to Ukraine, but they maintain a few options for when and how to do that.

This article cites a lot of timing uncertainty with the withdrawal, despite reports that all Russian personnel have been withdrawn: https://www.newsweek.com/ukraine-flag-kherson-city-russia-retreat-1758950
Ukrainian forces are now moving toward the city after the Russian retreat.
Nexta reports Ukraine claiming control of the city
AFU are in the city centerhttps://twitter.com/nexta_tv/status/1591058374019649538
Reduced slightly on the basis of this article talking about a potential trap left by Russians. Apparently, the Ukrainian forces are in no rush to move into the city
Reports of the Ukrainian military entering the city
Probably in the next few days if not already
As it seems

If I were Russia, I'd do this pullout well before I deem the safety of my soldiers in grave danger, so there may be a cushion period of time before the Ukrainians gain a stronghold, and it may take a couple or more days to fully withdraw. Then you have the chance of ambush and mines of sorts that could pose a risk for Ukrainians trying to get back into the city. I'm also not sure how quick and how sensitive the ISW map is.
According to this map:

Now, strategically Russia has two real options: force Ukraine to cease fire or withdraw from the occupied territories. I assume Putin prefers the first option. For this reason, they can quickly retreat to the eastern bank of the Dnieper or try to inflict painful losses in the delayed fighting in Kherson. The first should be done before November 25th. The second scenario is the possibility of withdrawing forces from the city, when the fight is very close and the Ukrainian artillery controls the river crossings. Rather, they may choose to fight ISIS-style (eg Mosul) with small forces (500-1000 men, Spetsnaz) that will be able to retreat to the other side after about 1-2 weeks. For this reason, I believe that the city council building should be recovered by the Ukrainians by November 25
Numerous reports that RU forces are retreating across Dnipro under artillery fire

Bumping 5% on possibility that RU withdrawal will turn into a rout. Lots of unconfirmed stories floating around; most of which will turn out to be false. My overall impression tho is that nearly all RU troops are already on the left bank, and that those that aren’t will collapse quickly.

The road from Mikolayev appears to be cleared almost to the city outskirts. The Russians still hold the city itself, however, and even if the Russians drag their feet in an actual withdrawal (as opposed to making the Ukrainians fight for Kherson), I doubt if the Ukrainians will attempt to chase them out of the city, and risk the damage. So with only 15 days to go, I'm staying at zero for now.

The Russian retreat is multifaceted in Kherson being under Ukrainian control: Media attention, lowered soldier morale, and somewhat as a tool for the Ukranians to be more hawkish, means that Kherson will likely be under Ukraine within at least the next month.
UA liberates at least 12 villages since retreat announcement. Heavier fighting will recommence closer to city
https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/ukrainian-forces-advance-south-capture-12-settlements-army-chief-2022-11-10/
Russia ordered a retreat from Kherson today. Unless it's a tactic to trick Ukraine into a false sense of security (which seems unlikely).

Well, Russia is giving up the westbank of the Dnipr river. But will still take some time how quickly, or better how carefully the Ukrainians are going to advance. There are going to be countless mines and booby traps on the way, and another obstacle the Russians are probably getting their troops out in time. And depending much of a jam there will be I'm also expecting some intense and ugly fighting. I'm not expecting the Ukrainians rushing for the sake of a speedy advance just to plant the flag on the building. But won't be for the last forcast on that question.
US said the withdrawal will take days or even weeks to execute, requiring RU to hold defensive positions near the river until everyone is across.
Adjusted due to more news: https://www.nytimes.com/2022/11/09/world/europe/ukraine-russia-kherson-retreat.html

The city council building is located in an area where there is reported Ukrainian partisan warfare. The AP News article reports that Ukrainian forces have been advancing toward the city of Kherson, and a professor quoted in the article predicts further Russian failures in Kherson. Further, a BBC article from October 19th states that, according to a Russia-installed local official, civilians and Russian officials are being relocated from Kherson in anticipation of Ukraine’s counter-offensive. Nevertheless, Ukrainian leaders say that Russian leaders are making these announcements in order to create hysteria and panic.
Timing could well be an issue.
I should know better than to fall into the trap of reading such news literally
—@James-B

Russian forces announced withdrawal from Kherson yesterday. According to some military observers - the retreat was requested a month ago, but Putin did not want to grant permission until US midterm elections! Ukraine is being cautious about sending in troops to retake Kherson fearing a trap, but takeover of the city by November 25th is looking increasingly likely.

Massive shift given Russia's news of withdrawal. It still remains to be seen whether Ukraine will control the building by the 25th, but it now seems more likely than not. Overcorrecting to make up for lost prior undercorrection!
Russia has withdrawn its military from the city today.

The Russian withdrawal looks to be taking place, so that's possibly significant. But it also depends upon whether the objective of the withdrawal is to consolidate Russian forces within and around the city, and force the Ukrainians to fight for it. So far, the Russian withdrawals appear to be in the northeast, toward Kherson (which given the position of the bridges is unavoidable anyway). But we'll see where they stop.

We're 16 days out. Which is plenty of time for Ukraine to move in and claim the area that includes the city council building if Kherson is truly abandoned by all forces. There's also this (Published Nov. 9 at 7:13 pm):
Based on recent retreat announced by the Russian defense minister.
Ukraine has regained control of the city on 8 Nov.
Rumors of a Russian withdrawal seem to be accurate.
11/9 : BBC is reporting, "Russia's military has been ordered to pull out of the Ukrainian city of Kherson, the only regional capital it captured..."
Russia just announced that they were leaving Kherson

It seems like this will happen, but it still is unclear when this will occur and whether Ukraine takes the fight to the retreating Russians/supply lines before officially reentering the city. Seems like partisans could take control of city before army officially takes over.
Russia has ordered its troops to retreat from Kherson. Transfer of control is imminent.
Based on Russian military retreating to the right bank of the Dnieper

Updating to reflect reportage of Russian troop withdrawals. Withdrawal is not a guarantee of a transfer of control as the date is not far off. Ground conditions may slow the Ukrainian advance and the Russian retreat.

On the one hand, with the withdrawal happening, Ukraine should advance quickly on the city and overrun it in no time. However, Russia is only retreating to behind the Dnipro river and I imagine they are going to shell the shit out of Kherson as Ukraine moves in so it might not be as easily won in just two weeks.
I am not extremely well versed on the probabilities for this – so I started from a 50-50 percent
Moderate optimism due to Russia announcement today.
WSJ article reports that Russian forces have withdrawn Kherson on 11/9.
Completely misjudged this. I think it was in hindsight still unlikely but not a 1 in 5 or lower chance. I’m over correcting a bit here to make up for that.

Still takes time to occupy Kherson after withdrawal. Ukraine advance could be slow due to caution. Ukraine likely wants this before the weather turns colder and both sides bunker in more. G20 could also effect this.

It looks like I was just in time with my previous post https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1542349 - Russians did announce the withdrawal from Kherson. Additional signs - they have withdrawn heavy artillery to the left bank already, also medical facilities and replaced them with roughly the same number of troops, but armed lightly, with machine guns etc.
Despite today's news, they could still blow the damn at Nova Kahhovka, which could lead to floods all the way down to Kherson. This would mean the building is not able to be captured
Lol ignore my incredibly badly timed previous post. The Russians have announced a full scale withdrawal across the Dnieper. I can only imagine it'll be chaos.
Pinballing around here....
On the other hand, you have reports that Russian flags are being removed across the city.
On 9 november the Russian defense minister orders troops to move to the eastern bank of the Dnipro, effectively surrendering Kherson

A Fermi-ization would look something like chances that (1) Ukraine takes over the city and the Russians actually leave especially the city council building, (2) the Kherson city council building survives and is also one of the areas Ukraine seizes control over, and (3) the ISW website reports this and also within the time frame of this question.

The commander has reported a withdrawing of Russian troops from Kherson, but there's conflicting reports that some Russian forces may still be in certain areas in Kherson, and more importantly that this may be an attempt to mislead. But I also doubt this because I think it's more likely this type of announcement to be a genuine one than a plan to mislead for strategic purposes.
Announcement has just been made that Russia is leaving the city
Recent news articles show that Ukrainian forces have moved into the key town north of Kherson

Bumping up my probability since Russia just announced that it was withdrawing from Kherson: https://www.nytimes.com/live/2022/11/09/world/ukraine-war-news-russia-updates. Still keeping a probability that it might not happen since Ukrainians are wary the Russians "might try to feign a retreat in hopes of drawing them into urban combat."
https://www.wsj.com/articles/ukrainian-forces-move-into-key-town-north-of-kherson-11667991035

I'm leaving a degree of uncertainty in case the news is wrong or this is a strategic feint by the Russian military, but the news is strongly suggesting that Ukrainian re-capture of Kherson is imminent
Recent news reports have Russian forces withdrawing from Kherson and Ukrainian forces making dramatic progress toward the city.
Russia withdrawing troops
On Russia announcing withdrawal from the region
+1pp because of reports that the deputy governor in Kherson died in a car crash.
The preparation on both sides is still underway, which signals a fierce battle that might take longer than the 25th to be settled.
I am not finding much news since late October on Ukraine's efforts in Kherson. Am I under a rock or are others experiencing similar?
On news of Stremnoussov death

No, the Russians have fortified their positions in and behind the city. Even with a sudden breakthrough (which is possibly in the works as of yesterday), the Ukrainians are not going to be in charge of the city centre in the next two weeks.
Russian channels say there will be an official announcement about Kherson tonight.
News about capture of snihurivka was fake. UA has taken positions in the city, but RU forces have not retreated
Accumulated evidence suggesting RU withdrawal. See recent my recent posts or @Greyowlsova ‘s last update for some rationale.
Did UA retake Snihurivka? I believe they did, and are now moving south. Based on videos, minor tidbits of news
So, the clarified narrative now is that Russians are going to abandon the city. Ukrainians are still doubting that will really happen. So, it most probably not 100% it will be happening.
Russia is retreating
Increasing estimate of UA attack. Decreasing estimate of committed Ru defense. Offset slightly by passage of another day
Russian forces have withdrawn... Civilian withdrawal done.. Ukrainian forces will likely take over

Ukraine on the other hand is still demolishing Russian logistics as per the last update on the ISW site.

UA insists they see no signs of retreat. Two minor stories are mildly suggestive: one was about aerial photos showing a new concentration of ships in Kherson since the 4th. Transport? The other stating that RU propagandists are being briefed on how to spin a retreat should Putin decide to order one.
It might be that Russia intends to leave that area

Within the time constraint, I do not think this is possible. Russian forces seem to be regrouping and the chances of Ukraine keeping control of this territory while being surrounded on all sides as per the ISW, within this time frame seems unlikely. Claiming control would mean this area would stop being marked red. Kherson has been a prized possession of the Russian forces since the beginning. Ceding control is not equal to removing the civilian population or removing the flag.
All eyes are on the weather and the clock.
Correcting for the passing of time.

It's mud season again. Mud favors the defenders. I think an offensive will wait until freeze up.

November 25th is less than 3 weeks away. I could be wrong, but I don't think a Russian retreat is imminent. If they fight for it, it will most likely take some time. That said, Insight Prediction, a real money market, has 42-45% for December 25th for Kherson.
Not changing forecast, yet, but this story has the most detail I’ve seen about ru defenses in Kherson. https://www.kyivpost.com/russias-war/russias-latest-plan-major-defensive-battle-for-kherson.html
Adjusting for the possibility of nobody really being in control of it, as in "being able to hold it", but Ukraine just raising a flag, similar to Zmeinyi island.

Russians have shown renewed preparations like reinforcing fortifications and sending additional forces, and Ukraine still to prepare/launch any decisive operation unlikely that Ukraine would be able to capture the building before Nov 25
Too little time even for a breakthrough.

ISOW overestimating likely Russian resistance, but time is running out for this challenge. RU cannot afford a costly battle for Kherson that could leave them too depleted to preserve their hold on the east/left bank as that could ultimately cost them Crimea. They will execute a fighting retreat to positions where the river is an asset rather than a hindrance.

My lowest probability in this situation yet, but current news has me change my forecast downward. https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/nov/05/ukraine-russian-troops-loot-kherson-as-lines-redrawn-ahead-of-final-battle-for-city.
Increasing estimate of ru putting up stiff resistance based on ISOW report

News reports suggest Russians digging in (also reports that they’re destroying boats in Kherson so either they’re forcing their troops to make a stand, or they’re preventing UA troops from crossing, or….).
Putin ordering retreats of civilians from the city Catch up: Putin calls for Kherson evacuation; strong hiring in America from TheEconomist
Passage of time. Three weeks is not enough.

Despite the Nov 3 ISW report stating that it is still unclear if Russian forces will fight for Kherson City, their reports of Russia's withdrawal make be suspect Russia will not contest the western side of the river where city council building is located. https://www.understandingwar.org

The general in charge of Kherson, which is situated in a Russian-controlled area of Ukraine, is merciless when it comes to his use of force. It’s worth noting, though, that there are militia-type forces in the area launching counteroffensives against Russian forces. A handful of experts anticipate additional Russian failures in Kherson, according to sources, which alludes to increasing momentum on the part of Ukraine; however, we still have a week and some change until mid-November, so anything could happen.
passage of time, map unchanged.

Bumping 5 on stories that RU forces are destroying communication and other infrastructure west of the Dnipro. Fwiw I suspect RU is pretending to be staying while evacuating rather than the other way around. But UA seems to think different
Temporarily bumping big (+30) on RU abandonment news...quite noisy and uncertain at the moment.
For what it's worth Ru removed Russian flag from Oblast Admin building. yesterday.www.france24.com and https://youtu.be/h3MuIUNCCzI

Why Putin will fight for Kherson: Fresh water and land bridge to Crimea https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/2022/11/03/kherson-kakhovka-water-crimea-battle/

ACCORDING to early reports coming out of Ukraine, the Russian flag that was flying above the main administration building in Kherson has been removed while checkpoints around the city have reportedly been abandoned.
Russian-appointed deputy governor of Kherson says Russian forces will “most likely” withdraw to eastern bank of Dnipro River. No time table given.

Member of Ukrainian reconnaissance team:
Reducing estimate of likelihood of stiff Russian resistance as Kherson Oblast government is moved to the South according to the guardian.

Assuming a 2/3 chance of an all-out Ukrainian attack in the time remaining, a 75% chance that Russian forces would make a serious defense, and a 25% chance UA can overcome that resistance in less than than 25 days.
Russia may blow the damn at Nova Kahhovka, which could lead to floods all the way down to Kherson. This would mean the building is not able to be captured

Down for the passage of time.
Conditions are improving for Ukraine to take Kherson, but not before this question closes.
• My base probability was 70% since there was a recent news report that Ukraine has recaptured 3 of the 5 areas that were under Russian control
https://www.thedailybeast.com/russia-is-losing-its-grip-on-ukrainian-city-of-kherson

I'm downgrading my forecast slightly after further consideration of Ukraine's recent attack on Sevastapol. Kherson is strategically essential if Russia seeks to maintain control of Crimea (home of their Black Sea Fleet). Because of this, I believe they will defend it with incredible vigor. If Ukraine takes Kherson, their advance toward the Crimea will soon follow. Russia simply cannot afford to allow that to happen.
Another day passes without significant movement in Kherson

Russian evacuation of their troops makes it seem like they may be wavering. Citizens in Kherson are apparently not accepting rubles which speaks to the sentiment on the ground. However, Putin is currently using a lot of force and still threatening the use of nuclear weapon, so I’m not completely positive on this outcome of Ukraine re-taking control yet.

Ongoing momentum and recent Ukrainian victories around Kherson, Ukraine increase the probability of retaking control of the city before 25 November, 2022. However, the base rate is Russia maintains control of Kherson and as a city in one of the four annexed regions, Russia will exert significant effort to maintain the city. Also, as the region enters winter, battles will likely become less frequent. Therefore, I believe it is more likely that Russia will maintain control of the city council building.
Russian forces will not retreat from Kherson. Evidence of Russia preparing for a prolonged defence
Giving each Ukrainian advantage a 10% increase in probability may have been too ambitious. Reduced to 5% to arrive at 65%
Since this is complex, I’ll try to use maxim 2 (go to a simple case).

Although Kherson is currently under Russian siege, Ukrainian counteroffensives are fast approaching this territory according to the Institute for the Study of War’s interactive map. In addition, as of october 24th, it was reported that Russian officials are fleeing the city to safer territory, suggesting an imminent Ukrainian takeover (https://www.nytimes.com/2022/10/24/world/europe/russia-ukraine-kherson-war.html).

it seems like it could be challenging to accomplish in the next 25 days. there seems to be weather issues that are impeding ukrainian forces. i'm adjusting my forecast downward. and will continue to monitor.

https://www.nytimes.com/2022/10/29/world/europe/ukraine-russia-war-artillery.html?campaign_id=2&emc=edit_th_20221029&instance_id=76066&nl=todaysheadlines&regi_id=77825025&segment_id=111501&user_id=dc6933c94fc82416d25dd297622374d1
Given that this situation is evolving in real time, I am currently 60-40 on Yes, and plan to monitor the events closely to see if this changes.

So far in the war, Ukraine has generally not regained territory. However, recent attempts by Ukrainian forces have been successful, and this will likely influence the motivation of Ukrainian soldiers to fight the Russians. My estimates are close to 50-50 as I consider it quite unpredictable what will happen, although I am leaning towards Ukraine not having control of Kherson.
There is a long way to go.
team's point that if Kherson is taken back by Ukraine, Russia will destroy the city council building. If it is destroyed, it can't be under Ukraine's control.

Though Ukraine is advancing fast and Russians talking of withdrawal. The advance may not be fast enough, location of building on the farther side of Russian controlled territory. Building may itself get destroyed so chances at 55 % within the deadline.
Down for the passage of time.
Russian evacuation of wounded soldiers, equipment and medicine from Kherson hospitals suggests they are leaving.

Although the Ukrainian offensive is making headway, the Russian military is simultaneously pivoting its approach toward attacks on civilians, which may affect the outcomes of fully taking over regions. As they advance the chances are increasing, but I would forecast the more they go east, the harder it will be to reclaim certain territories.
I pegged the probability to about 65% earlier since Ukraine was advancing to reclaim it according to reports, but updating it to make it lower to 33% because:

Kherson has served as a strategic center for Russia for several reasons. One is that the city offered a means of crossing the Dnieper River. The Ukrainians now aim to take control of Kherson; they intend to use the oblast and city as a jumping-off point for an attack on the south, thereby sealing the entrances to Crimea.
• Started with a base probability of 60%, given that one of the news reports suggested that Ukraine has re-captured 3 out of the 5 regions that are under Russian control.
Progress has been slow, but the collapse of Russian defenses may come quickly.

Admittedly, there is much to unpack here and many conflicting and overlapping sources to rely on in order to make—for me—a confident prediction. On the one hand, we have the four articles listed and linked above, but we also have warnings of Russian escalation in Kherson and with it the evacuation of the community in said city. And, on the other, there is U.S. Security Assistance (report) being sent to Ukraine across Fiscal Year 2021-23 and beyond that gives indication of empowering Ukrainians across provisional defense equipment and also humanitarian aid. Though the said aid schedule data is staggered and lags daily changes and updates to this conflict, it gives an idea of what past and future aid is headed to the conflict zone(s) across the war torn territories. Keep these two splits in question, my initial forecast is at a 38% for a “Yes” outcome.
Most advances and counters by Ukraine seem to be in the east, and there's only 1 month before Nov 25.

I expect Ukraine to make several gains in Kherson in the next 2-3 weeks, however, the deeper one gets into a city, the greater the advantage the defender holds. Moreover, the odds of Russia delivering a nuclear attack are increasing. It’s difficult to predict whether the Ukrainian army will be able to hold the city council building by November 15, but it is entirely possible.
Very little progress in 18 days and only 27 left.

I changed my forecast to 30%-70% because a. Putin has drawn a line at Kherson as it’s a referendum held territory so it’s unlikely it will be attacked. However, the new general took over a week ago, and has become a unified single commander. But overall, as Ukraine has taken back some of its previously acquired territory we expect it to hold its ground at Kherson.

I believe that it is likely because Russia has escalated its attack recently. However, Kyiv's southern military command said the Ukrainian armed forces have retaken more than 400 square kilometres since the start of October. So its only 60% likely.

Ukrainian forces continue their advance and were able to conduct a drone strike on Sevastapol this weekend. This suggests their capability and boldnesses continues to increase and increases the likelihood that they might take the city council building.
- Russians say draft is now complete for the time being; signals there is no demand for troops and Russia's military leaders are satisfied with progress

What would have to be true for the council building to be under Ukraine’s control? Russia's movement eastward, pressure from Ukrainian forces from the west, troop availability in the area for both forces, and local availability of fighting resources. It seems clear that Ukraine’s push has been focused on the southern regions and Russia also advised civilian evacuation from the west of the Dnipro to the east. Given all else being equal, and Ukraine’s growing counteroffensive from the west to the east, I would give odds in favor of Ukraine capturing the city council building.

- The city council currently falls in the Reported Ukrainian Partisan Warfare region. This means that there are rebels operating in the region that are working to destroy the Russian army's weapons and supply lines, pass information to the Ukrainian military, and demoralize the occupying forces.

This is a much more complex problem with less data. The data we do have may help us though. So far, Ukraine has reclaimed ~15-20% of the land taken by Russia. US military doctrine gives a 3-1 advantage to defense over offense. Winter is approaching. Russia has “formally” annexed the region where Kherson lies. These all point to the difficulty of retaking Kherson and lead to my low probability assessment.

Movement has been very slow in Kherson oblast, apart from a sudden change a week ago. The Russians are under a lot of pressure with a terrible supply situation, but have dug in and mostly held their ground. Makes it hard to know when they will break.

The Ukrane maintains the momentum.

From an outside view, there is a general momentum on the side of the Ukrainians given recent advances of Ukrainian troops in the North and South of the country, and deliveries of advanced Western weapons systems. The city of Kherson is the number one liberation target for the Ukrainian forces and has a very symbolic character as the only administrative capital of Ukraine that the Russians managed to illegally annex. Given these trends, the likelihood of Ukraine succeeding is likely in the 40-60% range.

Based on more recent reports, Russia is not withdrawing from Kherson rather they are getting their troops ready for a counter-offensive, though even if a full scale clash happens I think Ukraine will most likely be successful in the counter offensive given that their troops are still better prepared and trained, and based on their recent successes. But it may take longer than 25th November, which is why I have adjusted the forecast slightly (from 63% to 60%) .

An outside-ish view: Since September, Ukraine has been winning battles and taking back control of major cities such as Lyman. This has led to reports of an overall decrease in Russian troops’ morale and increased mobilization of less trained military forces. An unmotivated and more amateur military increases the likelihood of Ukrainian forces having more successes.

Arguments for: Russians have already began moving a lot of civilians away from the area as well as its own troops suggesting that it is willing to give up this territory. Ukraine has made good progress in the last few months compared to the beginning of the invasion with more tactical weapons flowing into the area which has cut off the Russian ability to reinforce Kherson. Arguments against: Weather may hamper general progress in the vicinity. Russia is also waging a lot of prestige on keeping this vicinity. Russians might be able to get more troops given its latest mobilization.

Additionally, Russia needs to not shell the city and destroy the City Hall building for Ukrainian to take it over.

While Ukraine has done exceedingly well in its counter-offense against Russian forces, it has taken nearly two months for them to reclaim only half of the territory occupied by Russia north of Kherson. The region stretching from Kherson to the Ukrainian front is primarily flat farmland, devoid of forests and other natural obstacles. With winter coming, this open approach will become a dangerous obstacle for maneuver forces. To cover this open stretch, Ukrainian forces must generate a large maneuver force with deep artillery and air coverage. The forces and level of coordination required for such an operation will be challenging to achieve. Thus far, Ukraine has had most of its success fighting a mobile defense in wooded areas. While their success in this arena has been outstanding, I do not feel that Ukraine's success in an irregular defense equates to a high probability of success in offensive maneuver warfare.

Maybe a 1 in 3 chance. On the one hand, the Ukrainian side has been largely trying to avoid urban warfare in which it is the attacker. This article explains all the advantages that defenders have in urban combat: https://mwi.usma.edu/the-eight-rules-of-urban-warfare-and-why-we-must-work-to-change-them/

Very uncertain about this question. We have 20 days before end of the question, with fighting occurring around Kherson. However, it is surrounded by territories under Russian control and it might therefore be difficult for the Ukrainian army to hold Kherson while being surrounded by Russian army. Moreover, it is ambiguous whether the Russian regained territory was previously retaken by Ukraine in their counteroffensive or not. If so, then Ukraine has lost some territory next Kherson recently which would push predictions towards “no”.

The aim of the occupation of the Kherson region is also to seize the northern security of Crimea. If Kherson is controlled by Ukraine, Russians cannot be safe in Crimea. Any possible interference with the river and dam line north of Kherson could have different consequences for Ukraine or different for Russia, regardless of which side takes it. The slope will be towards the south, so I see a low probability of Russia realizing this. My thought is almost 50%. But 10% percent. A Kherson showdown or a side's failure to admit defeat can heat things up.

I gave Ukraine a 60 percent probability of reclaiming the territory because of reports that the Russian military is ill-equipped and exhausted. Also, Russian troop morale is reportedly much lower than that of Ukrainian soldiers (and civilians). I still give Russian a 40 percent chance given the recently reported mobilization of 300,000 Russian soldiers.

In terms of decision analysis, the Russians have two choices, broadly defined: hold and defend Kherson OR cut their anticipated losses and withdraw. The answer to whether the city council building will be in Ukrainian control is strongly associated with which of the two scenarios above pans out.

Overall, I have been amazed with both the resolve, resilience and mental fortitude that the Ukrainian forces (and its civilian population) have demonstrated ever since the Russian invasion started. Conversely, I have also been impressed with the Russian incompetence as well with its very unprofessional and unprepared Army. Therefore, there is a good chance that Kherson is recaptured by the brave Ukrainians. In the article, Professor Phillips P. From forecaster on Metaculus (https://www.metaculus.com/questions/10850/date-of-ukrainian-liberation-of-kherson/):

The war has been going on since February this year and we have seen the first successful counteroffensives of Ukraine only at the beginning of this month. So, Ukraine reconquering territory is not an event that has happened very often during the overall war. However, the recent attempts from Ukrainian forces have been successful, and this will probably influence Ukrainian soldiers’ motivation to fight Russians. Russian army, on the other hand, may respond more aggressively to stop Ukraine’s counteroffensive. Russia is also more prepared to deal with Ukranian counter-offensives right now than it was a few weeks ago when Ukraine started to reconquer territory.
Ukraine has been militarily advancing steadily, but the Russians' call to evacuate the city means they will use maximum force to defend it, making it difficult to control the whole city by the 25th.

Kherson is in “assessed Russian control” territory and is only 150km from Crimea, a territory controlled and claimed by Russia since its first invasion of Ukraine in 2014. Yet, Kherson is also only 80 km away from Ukrainian controlled Mykolaiv and just next to territory recently re-claimed by Ukrainian counter offensives. Furthermore, Kherson is in “reported Ukrainian counter offensives territory” and the Ukrainian army has made important recent advances in the territories nearby. As the building is a symbol of the city, Ukrainian counteroffensives may capture it (or better, recover it) before they regain the whole area. I hence give a higher probability that the building will be under Ukrainian control by 15 November.
Could do; though I think it to be a temporary hold.

I’m coming at this question from a place of close emotional attachment, as I lived in Kherson for 9 months in 2017 and 2018 and feel a deep love and admiration for the people living there, and for Ukraine generally. I eagerly want Ukraine to reestablish control over the city, but I am trying to temper my desires for a certain outcome when analyzing the situation and forecasting probabilities. Given the impressive lightening counteroffensive the Ukrainian forces have orchestrated in the past month, it feels as though military momentum is on their side. Also, my understanding is that informal partisan violence against Russian occupying forces and civil disobedience toward administrative officials have been particularly intense in Kherson, relative to other occupied cities, suggesting that there will be internal pressure easing the way for the Ukrainian offensive into the city. There is also news about how Russian occupying administrative officials have begun evacuating from the city, suggesting that the Russian government recognizes that its hold over the city is at risk. These on their own would put my baseline prediction at around 70%.

The Ukrainian counteroffensive has made some impressive gains in the last few weeks, as reported in the media. However, according to the Study of War map, the majority of reclaimed Ukrainian territory has been in northern Eastern Russia, near Kharkiv. Russian troops are more mobilized in the South near Crimea, where Kherson is located. While I would not be surprised if Ukrainian troops continue their impressive forays into occupied territory and reclaimed Kherson, Russia will defend it mightily.

Eight months into this war, it is apparent that Ukraine has senior commanders who are seasoned strategists and operational planners. These leaders have the measure of their adversary. They understand how to balance strategic risk and opportunity and are clearly skilled at guiding their subordinates through the planning and execution of campaign-level military endeavors. This is an uncommon proficiency that few military institutions possess. In the Ukrainians, this is founded on their knowledge of Soviet operational theory which has been refined in pre-war nato training and with battlefield experience.

Initial highly subjective forecast. My sense is that Russia won’t let this city go easily and will commit many additional resources to holding it. I think 50:50 here is the right place right now. In this region, Ukraine has better morale, better equipment, better troops, and has made some vast gains as of late. On the other hand, they haven't reached the city yet and urban fighting favors the defense. Additionally, as many people have mentioned in their forecasts, it would be a major loss of face to Russia if they lose Kherson.
The city council building is on the west bank. Russian army is said to be leaving. Ukrainian army is stronger.

I estimate that the city council building in Kherson will be not under Ukrainian control on 25 November. I acknowledge that the Ukrainian armed forces have achieved sustained advances and civilians are fleeing and Russian troops are increasingly under pressure. But events within the last two weeks suggest that finishing the drive into Kherson and retaking the city council building will not be easy. First, the defense (i.e. Russia) holds an advantage when fighting in urban terrain. While Kerson is not a huge city, there are still four rivers they need to cross before getting into the city and 20-30 blocks they’ll need to clear of Russia forces. This is no small task if the Russian defenses remain in place and fight. Russia is also bombing cities and infrastructure at an astonishing pace. The city council building may not even be standing by 25 November. If it is, there is a chance that it will be radioactively toxic or that it will be underwater as Russia has threatened both ‘dirty bombs’ and flooding to prevent Ukraine from regaining the city.

I don't think it will happen in the next month. The lines in Kherson are stable now - anyway, that's what the maps say. This may just be both sides want to keep movements one way or the other from becoming public. But assuming the maps are right, and assuming the rate of advance over the next month is maintained by the Ukrainian Army, they won't make it to Kherson unless the Russians evacuate all their fighting power in the next month, which I consider impractical even if the Russians wanted to do it.

25 Nov seems a little soon. Yes Russia looked like it might be withdrawing, but to lose such a big city would be a major loss of face and there is no way they’d let it go easily. Ukraine has yet to reach the city outskirts, and then they have to get to the city centre and then take the symbolic building.

The city of Kherson is currently under assessed Russian control and has been for some time. The city is also within the zone that Russia held a sham referendum and declared officially Russian territory (via annexation). Russia is in the process of increasing its fighting force and it likely working hard to avoid losing any major perceived victories at this stage. Russia’s new commander of forces, Air Force General Sergei Surovikin, is also known for ruthlessness and an unquestioning following of orders, which suggests that Russia may use more radical means to defend its hold of the city.

Russian troops have occupied the Kherson City Council building since April 2022 and after Putin’s announcement of the illegal annexation of the four Ukraine provinces, I believe that there is more pressure on Russia to maintain a military hold over Kherson and these southern regions because of this publicly broadcast pronouncement. Based on the interactive map, Ukrainian forces will need to advance 50-75km in less than a month and also establish control in the Russian-occupied city in order to gain access to the city council building. I also think there is a decent chance that the building will not even be standing by 15 November if missile strikes continue.
